0: An incredibly rare octopus invasion of a Welsh beach may have been caused by recent storms that battered the Irish Sea, experts fear. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR More than 20 of the solitary creatures were spotted coming out of the water in New Quay, Ceredigion, and crawling up the beach on three consecutive nights, baffling locals, who have never witnessed such a phenomenon. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The curled octopuses, a common species in British waters, are very secretive creatures and usually found at depths of up to 100m. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR James Wright, curator at the National Marine Aquarium in Plymouth, said he had heard one or two other accounts last week of some being found in the intertidal zone - where the tide comes in and out - along the North Devon and the Welsh coasts. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “This account of a number on the same beach is quite odd,” he told the Telegraph. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “But them even being found in the intertidal is not common and suggests there is something wrong with them I am afraid. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “As the areas where they are exhibiting this odd behaviour coincides with the two areas hit by the two recent low pressures depressions
